ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Continued learning of Yorb language. More emphasis on tones (which are very difficult) and new vocabulary such as ceremonies, travel, abbl

I learn new concepts of the language Yoruba this semester. I learn new topics that I could use in the everyday life such as food, traffic, ceremonially services, and more. This course helped me develop a better understanding of the language.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
The strengths are that we talk a lot in the language and then we get to practice a lot with the assignments we are given.
There are not really any weakness!

strengths: fun easygoing professor, pretty low workload, learn a lot of yoruba
weaknesses: needs more emphasis on speaking with the homework assignments, more practice with tones

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Continue taking Yorb. Continue, continue, continue. I feel like after a few levels, ones Yorb can advance so much. After L2, you can work around Lagos well enough.
Yes I would. It is a very informative class and you can learn a lot about the language and the Nigerian culture!
yes! wonderful course with a lot of student interaction and the professor and TA are excellent, warm, personable individuals.
yes would recommend! yoruba is really fun and prof seye makes it a blast. he makes it a super painless experience and the grading is lenient. take yoruba!!!
